{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3162067,"name":"Christopher149","username":"Christopher149","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/838e76/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-11T04:08:48.771Z","cooked":"

On our robot we have a wrist mechanism for the intake that is driven by a NEO through a 125:1 MAXPlanetary and a 16:48 chain reduction to the intake forearm. The chain spacing is using a REV 3:1 ratio plate with 72 chain links as printed on the ratio plate as correct.

In the time before our week 1 event I thought I remember the chain being fairly tight, but now there seems to be enough slack/backlash that if we could remove 1/8" of chain would resolve (i.e. half of a 1/4" link, or where trying to stretch tight the chain rollers want to sit on points of the sprocket teeth). We tried placing a piece of 1x1 below the chain run to take up some slack but the chain was catching on the corner of the 1x1 annoyingly. We also tried swapping the chain for fresh 25H but have the same slop. There is some slop to the position of the main wrist axle that we can’t really account for, but mechanically it’s REV maxtube grid → Thrifty Bot bearing hat → hex bearing → churro → MAX spline endcap → MAX spline → REV 48t spline sprocket.

I think this backlash is causing some jerkiness lowering the intake as the bottom of the chain goes taut, the intake goes over center and slackens the bottom, repeat a couple times until it settles. We are already controlling position with a REV through bore encoder on the the actual wrist axle so we have a nice absolute position.

Here’s a photo of the setup. Sorry that I don’t have any of the chain looseness.

IMG_05941920×1280 185 KB

Any suggestions? As built there isn’t room I think for an inline chain tensioner, but the ratio plate should have avoided that need I think. Or should we move the motor further back to get room for the tensioner?

For a quick fix put a zip tie around the middle of your chain. This works surprisingly well and is very durable. For extra insurance add a second one.
